manipulated_prompt_obj.inputs:
human: Provide one single-word clue that relates to some of your team's words from the list below. You can choose to how many and to which words your clue relates to.
The goal is to have your partner guess all of your team's words based on the clues you give them, before the other team has uncovered all of theirs. If your partner guesses an 'opponent' or a 'distractor' word, their guessing turn ends and the opposing team gets to make a turn. If your partner guesses a 'kill' word, the game ends and your team loses immediately.
The more words your clue relates to, the quicker you can win the game, but the harder the associations may be to guess for your partner, so choose your clue word wisely. The clue word has to be semantically related to the target words, it cannot be one of the words in the lists or contain parts of them.

Always give your single-word clue and your comma-separated list of related target words in the following format and make your answers as short as possible, never include any other text than is required in this form:

CLUE: <WORD>
TARGETS: <TARGETS>

Your team words are: friend, difference, report, dad, accident, middle, drink, age, sister.
Your opponent's team words are: colonel, gold, bank, street, ladies, fun, couple, record.
Distractor words are: bar, sir, mom, news, plane, country, order.
The kill words are: kind. <sep> assistant:

raw_response_obj.response:
human: Provide one single-word clue that relates to some of your team's words from the list below. You can choose to how many and to which words your clue relates to.
The goal is to have your partner guess all of your team's words based on the clues you give them, before the other team has uncovered all of theirs. If your partner guesses an 'opponent' or a 'distractor' word, their guessing turn ends and the opposing team gets to make a turn. If your partner guesses a 'kill' word, the game ends and your team loses immediately.
The more words your clue relates to, the quicker you can win the game, but the harder the associations may be to guess for your partner, so choose your clue word wisely. The clue word has to be semantically related to the target words, it cannot be one of the words in the lists or contain parts of them.

Always give your single-word clue and your comma-separated list of related target words in the following format and make your answers as short as possible, never include any other text than is required in this form:

CLUE: <WORD>
TARGETS: <TARGETS>

Your team words are: friend, difference, report, dad, accident, middle, drink, age, sister.
Your opponent's team words are: colonel, gold, bank, street, ladies, fun, couple, record.
Distractor words are: bar, sir, mom, news, plane, country, order.
The kill words are: kind. <sep> assistant: <reasoning>
Let's tackle this clue-giving problem. The user's team has words like friend, difference, report, dad, accident, middle, drink, age, sister. I need to find a single-word clue that relates to as many of these as possible without being one of the words themselves or containing parts of them.

First, I'll look for common themes. Let's list out the words again:

Friend, difference, report, dad, accident, middle, drink, age, sister.

Looking for connections. Friend and sister are family members. Dad is also family. So family is a possible theme. But maybe there's a better connection. Let's see:

Friend – maybe relationships? Difference could relate to conflict or comparison. Report might be about communication. Dad is family. Accident is an event. Middle is a position. Drink is a verb. Age is a noun. Sister is family.

Alternatively, think of categories. Family: friend, dad, sister. But friend isn't a direct family member. Maybe relationships in general. But maybe other angles.

Difference could relate to "contrast" or "divide". Report could be "news" but that's a distractor. Accident is an event. Middle is a position. Drink is a verb. Age is a noun. Hmm.

Wait, "middle" could relate to "center". "Difference" could be "divide". Maybe "divide" as a clue? Let's see: divide relates to difference,
